responses:
Alright then. 
1.Expression: Ranges from joy, disbelief to insults. There are positive, negative and neutral expressions. 
2.Greeting: How to exchange pleasantries... It is only positive. 
3. Traits: A trait or habit observed or assigned to a person. It can be positive, negative or neutral. 
4.Action: May involve more than one person, action taken individually or an event. Can be negative, positive or neutral. 
5.Praise: To celebrate, elate or bless... It is only positive but may also be used in a sarcastic manner, depending on the situation. 
6. Sentences & phrases: short and basic. It is mostly neutral or negative.
Please pick a category and indicate if you want to know the positive, negative or neutral. 
Example: To know positive expressions, simply type 'Expression Positive'.

O ti Zeh: (oh-tee-zeh) Meaning: It has clicked or worked out 
Example: The contract don Zeh.. O ti zeh.

I dont wanna be a mechanic, I wanna be a baller: 
This slang started on TikTok, where random people express their desires to live lavish lifestyles and avoid the life of a mechanic(considered as poor/poverty).
Betta dey?/Any betta?: Anything good? / any good news?.

Ko Po Ke or KPK(koh-kpo-keh):
Means isn't it abundant/ plenty/many/surplus?. 
Typically used in celebratory situations. 
Example: you bought a house, a car, threw a lavish party etc. The response will be: O po Pa/O po Gan or OPP/OPG (oh-kpo-kpa or oh-kpo-gun). 
It is an acknowledgement that it is indeed abundant/surplus/plenty/ many.

Who dey breet?: 
Means Who is breathing/awake?. Coined by Davido.
Meaning: A term used to draw attention to something impressive. Similar to 'e choke' 
Example: Tobi got new shoes and so he steps out in them or maybe records them as he says 'who dey breet?' .
It is not restricted to any situation and can be used anytime.

Oporr (oh-kpor): 
A term to hail someone for having something in abundance.

Notin Spoil/ notin do you: Means all is well. Used when a mistake is made and you wish to let someone know you have no issues with them and its alright. 
It may also be used as a form of praise to mean you are without blemish or are doing great.

Butta my bread: Answered prayers. 
Example: God don butta my bread which means God has answered my prayers.(butta = butter)

Jaiye lo(jah -yay-law): 
Meaning: To enjoy life. 
Example: Jaiye lo my friend, you earned it.

Aza (ah-zah): 
Meaning: Bank details. 
Example: Can I send my aza?.

Pepper (peh-peh or pair-pair) don rest:
 money has come or I have a lot of money (inflow).

Jara(jah-rah): 
Jara is a noun derived from the Yoruba language and it means to add extra or give a freebie after
something has already been bought or paid for, at the sellers discretion. Example: Please add jara.

Loud:
Meaning: Something makes sense. Used to express how undeniable something is. Used when you agree with something being said. 
You may say Loud am (let everyone know). Alternatively, you may use it to ask someone to keep something private. 
Example: No loud am (dont let people know).

E choke:
Started by famous Nigerian singer, David “Davido” Adeleke. 
'E Choke' literarily means 'It Chokes', however, in the street language, it is an exclamatory remark 
for something overwhelming or extremely impressive.
When Nigerians see something or someone that is impressive or does something that exceeds expectation, 
this expression is used as a way of saying that they were so surprised that they choked on air 
or on their saliva. It may be a bit exaggerated.

No be me and you. Meaning: Literally means it is not you and I. A dramatic way to say 'NEVER!!!'. To express and over emphasize to another person that you will not be going or doing whatever is being asked/demanded of you

Motor don jam am: Meaning: A term derived from the song 'Egungun(eh-goon-goon) be careful' by the artist 'Obasere' it is used as a form of expression to convey that someone has faced the consequences of their actions.
E don enter one chance. Meaning: To fall into a trap, to find yourself in an unfavourable situation unexpectedly or ignorantly

kasala don burst/yawa don gas (kah-sah-lah/yah-wah): 
There is trouble.
Which kind wahala be dis?: What kind of problem is this. Used to express frustration.

1. You don cook beans: You screwed up. 

2. Juju/jazz:
Meaning: voodoo. Example: Tope used juju/jazz on her boyfriend.

Werey dey disguise (way-ray): 
A person who pretends/tries to hide their true colors. 
Used to call out the fake person or to tell(warn) others of the person. Wolf in sheep clothing.
Example: A Corrupt politician who acts caring and concerned when elections are around the corner 
or the lazy staff who poses as a hard worker whenever the boss is around.

70 years old man: 
Typically used to shame an adult male(advanced in years) who behaves childishly/shamefully.
Our mumu no too much? Mumu=(moo-moo):Translation: Haven't we been foolish for long enough.

Sapa:(sah-kpa): 
To be broke (poverty).

Village pipo (people pronounced pee-po): 
Enemies of progress. Derived from common plots in old Nigerian movies where family members from a persons 
home town or close friends resort to voodoo in order to ensure the person does not succeed at anything.

Street: Ghetto neighbourhood. 
Example: Bro, I m from the steets.

Getat: 
Get out, Fuck off.

Who you epp?: 
Meaning1: Who have you helped or uplifted? 
Meaning2. What have you done that is worthy of respect?.
Often used to deflate the ego of a person prone to bragging and/or showing off their wealth.

Gbam!: 
From the Igbo tribe.
Meaning: To concur, agree completely, exactly, precisely.

I no get anytin to tell you: 
Meaning: I have nothing to say to you or I have no words.

I no get: i dont have. 
Example: If you re shopping you might say I no get basket of tomatoes for house. 
This means, I dont have a basket of tomatoes at home.

God Abeg: God Please. To plead to God 
Example: God abeg run am for me. Run am -> (do it).
1. Dem send you? : Have you been sent to torment me?. Dem in this context would mean unknown enemies.

K-leg: Questionable.
Example: Your story get k-leg! Which means your story or gist sounds suspect or exaggerated.

I go change am for you o:
A warning to a person being annoying. It is to inform them that your calm demeanor will not last much longer if they continue to annoy you.

Vex : Upset. 
Example: no vex me! Or no dey do wetin dey vex me; Which means: 
Dont upset me! Or stop doing things that annoy me .You may add abeg at the end which in this situation as rude plea.
Na me fuck up/ Na me do myself: I brought this upon myself/I did this to myself.

1. Fall my hand: To be disappointed, to let down, to embarrass.

2. You Pour sand for my garri: You have sabotaged my plans, you have ruined my plans.

Dem no born you well. Meaning1: 
You wouldn't dare. 
Meaning2: You wont try it. 
Meaning3: Fuck around and find out.

Trenches: Trenches is used to refer to the ghetto or an environment below the basic human living standard. 
It is also used to describe a state of mind.

Shege(shay-gay): 
The term has its origin in the Hausa(how-sah) language. 
It means to suffer greatly or to express the state of a person going through tough times or challenging situations. 
Example: my eyes don see shege (I have suffered greatly).

Stories that touch: Similar to werey dey disguise. It is used in situations where it is obvious that someone is playing 
the victim and is making up sob stories to get sympathy, or to get their way

E shock you. Meaning: You're shocked?, Are you surprised?. This term is used when someone does something unexpected; especially in a situation where the action taken was the last thing anybody could have ever imagined. It is the equivalent of 'uno reverse'
Awoof (ah-woof). Meaning: Free stuff/giveaway. Example: Mr John too like awoof.This means Mr John likes free stuff or is cheap.

1. Anytin for me?: Do you have anything for me (used when begging for money or food). 
Typically used when asking for a bribe or begging outright

Ko necessary (co-necessary): It isn't necessary. 
Used when a person is doing the most for no reason.

No be juju be dat?: 
A term used when someone is surprised or shocked by situation or the actions of another that seems almost magical or too shocking/unbelievable. It means isn't this magic.

Mafo (mah-fuh): 
Used in a song by the artist-Naira marley. It means dont worry, dont be bothered.

We meuve(we move): First heard in big brother Naija(Nigeria) from Vee whose foreign accent made the word move sound like meeoove. 
It is now used by Nigerians as a form of self-motivation to keep going when things dont go as planned. It simpler terms, life goes on.

You want to bamba (bam...bah): 
A person who wants to hang around/ be indoctrinated into the inner circle of the rich and powerful or dangerous and violent. 
Either way it is to join a society or group that they may not be equipped to handle.

Cut soap for me: 
Means show me the way. Typically said to people considered to be financially successful. To be used in lighthearted situations.

Urgent 2k: 
Meaning: Emergency funds often demanded during hard times. 
Example: I am tired of them reaching out to me only when they need urgent 2k.

Las las: 
Meaning: Eventually.
Example: We will be fine las las.

Iffa hear/ Nor be only(nor-be-ownlay): 
Meaning: A term used to portray disbelief. Same as a sarcastic yeah right.
Now now or na na: Immediately.

E be like film:
This phrase is used to express incredulity, especially when reporting a scenario or circumstance. 
Example: A person recounting an accident that happened quickly could say:
Di way wey di car tumble ern, e be like film!. 
Translation: The way the car tumbled was just like in the movies, or incredible.
You may also say  e be like magic(its just like magic)

Ehen (air-hain): This exclamation can be and is used in many ways.
Depending on the context in which it was used,It means but is not limited to the following: Meaning1:'I get it', Meaning2:'And so?',Meaning3: 'Is that so?', Meaning5: 'Yes', 
Meaning6: 'continue', Meaning7:'As i was saying', Meaning8: 'that reminds me', Meaning9: 'exactly'.

1. Abeg(ah-beg): 
Meaning: Please.
Example: Abeg forgive her.

2. Wetin(way-teen): 
Meaning: What?. 
 Example: Wetin you want?

3. Otilor (oh-tee-law): 
 Meaning: It is gone.

1.Comot!(cor-mort): 
Meaning  go ,  move ,  leave , or  get out! . 
Example: Make we comot (Let us go out)- friendly speech.
2. Comot for there (leave that place or getout)- Rude speech. Example: Comot for road (Move out of the way).
Na me be dis?: Is this happening to me?

Your eye don detty: 
You are drunk or high

1. No vex: 
Meaning: Do not be angry. Used to pacify an angry person. 
Example: Abeg, no vex bro, na mistake.

1. Jogor(jaw-gaw): 
Meaning: To be high. 
Example: I don jogor.

2. Detty: High or intoxicated. 
Example: My eyes don dirty.

1. Walahi: 
A word from the Hausa(how-sah) tribe that means sincerely or truthfully .

2. Koro/Lungu (caw-raw/loon-goo): 
Koro is borrowed from Isoko(ee-sow-co) tribe and Lungu is of the Hausa(how-sah) Tribe:
Meaning: short cut , dark alley or dirt road depending on the context it is used.

Obodo Oyibo (oh-bow-doe-yee-bow): 
Borrowed from the Igbo(ee-bow or ee-gbow) tribe. 
It means  white-mans land .

Kia-kia: Borrowed from the Yoruba(your-uber) tribe which means quickly-quickly.
Say it twice to emphasize the urgency.

Wahala be like bicycle: 
A popular slang in 2021, used in unpleasant situations. 
People may might describe a difficult situation by starting with saying wahala be like bicycle before narrating the story.

You gerrit?... If u dont gerrit forgerra-bou-rrit: 
Means  Do you understand?...if you dont understand, forget about it. . Nigerian version of IYKYK (if you know, you know)

1. Bone datin(dah-teen): forget that thing, Ignore it. 
You may simply say bone to mean forget, ignore, leave it be or let it go. 
 2. Bone/strong may also be used to describe seriousness. 
Example: Why you dey bone/strong face? (why do you look so serious or upset?).

I wan chop or I dey H: 
Unlike the English word, chop which implies that something is being sliced or hacked; in pidgin(Nigerian english) it means food. 
I wan Chop or I dey H means I want to eat or I am hungry.

Incase of Incasity: To take precaution and avoid problems or hiccups that may ruin plans. 
Example: save the file o incase of incasity

G/Gee: 
Meaning: Close friend. Plural: Gees. 
Example: You are my gee, Thanks G.

Comrade: 
Meaning: A person you can relate to.
Example: You are a fellow comrade.
Charge and bail. Meaning: A term used to describe an unaccomplished/unsuccessful lawyer.

1. Ment: Mental problem. Used as an insult.
Example: You dey ment?: Have you gone nuts?.

2. Kala (kah-lah) / Aka-Gum (ah-kah-gum)
Meaning: To be stingy. 
Example: That guy kala, That guy na Aka gum.

3. Amebo: 
(ah-may-baw) 
This word is used to refer to a person who likes to gossip or spread gossip and cannot be trusted. 
It can also be used to refer to gossip itself. Example: You too like amebo or That girl is an amebo.

Ode: 
(uh-deh) 
Meaning1: A fool. Synonym: Mumu.
Example: Chinedu na ode. 
Meaning2: A sarcastic pet name lovers or people with a crush call each other. Example: Ode, how are you?
Mumu (moo-moo): Meaning- A fool. Synonym: Ode. Example: You be mumu .

1.Ojoro (oh-joe-roe): Cheat. 
2. Wayo: 
(wah-yoh): Trickery.
Example:That man be wayo; which means  that man is a fraud!. 
3. Ojoro na wayo(oh-joe-roe nah-wah-yo): Cheat or cheater. 
To cheat on a game or to deceive in order to gain advantage. 
Usually in a lighthearted situation.

Bad belle (bell-air(british pronunciation): envy or intense jealousy. 
Example: this man na/get bad belle (this man is prone to/is an envious/ jealous person).
Area boys: Street-smart young men that loiter around neighborhoods.

Ashewo or ashawo: 
(ah-shair-woe) or (ah-shah-woe)
Meaning: Slut, Whore or Prostitute. A derogatory term for men and women considered loose.

Kolo (co-low): 
Meaning: To go crazy or mad. This can mean literally or metaphorically depending on the context. 
Example: He don kolo.

Yoruba demon:
Meaning: A charming man who has a way with words, knows how to attract women and 
consistently/without fail serves them breakfast(Heart-break and/or devastation). 
Example: Most Yoruba demons are named Femi.

Weyrey (way-ray): 
Meaning: A mad/crazy person. 
 Example: That guy na weyrey.

Olodo (oh-load-oh): 
Meaning: Someone who is intellectually dull. 
Example: He was an olodo back in secondary/high school.
1. Oga( uh-gah ): Boss or leader(typically male). 2.Madam:(pronounced 'mah damme') : Boss, leader (typically female).

Ajebutter(ah-jair-boar-tah). Ajebutter, ajebo,  bota  or  botti , simply refers to one who is born with a silver spoon.
It also means someone regarded as 'out of touch' or generally soft(coddled). 
Example: That babe is an ajebutter.
Lepa/Orobo (leh-kpa)/ (ore-raw-baw) Lepa is a noun that refers to a skinny person. Orobo is loosely the opposite of lepa. It refers to a fat person.

Over-sabi (ovah-sah-bee): This is a noun referring to someone who is a busy-body, is pedantic, a know it all 
or mocking someone who shows-off his/her intelligence/knowledge especially if it is not called for. 
Example: I did not ask you, over-sabi.
Moneybag: Meaning A rich person. Example: That girl has become a moneybag since she started dating the Yahoo boy.

1. Momcy (mom-see): Meaning- Common substitute used to say mother. Example: I would ask momcy if she can make it there.

2. Popcy (pop-see): Meaning - Common substitute used to say father.
Example: Popcy gave me his old car
Efizi (eh-fi-zi): Means show off. Can be negative or positive depending on the situation

responses: The thing make brain. Meaning: The thing is very good/nice/lovely/impressive/attractive. A way to say you are pleased/impressed. Example: This food make brain or the the car make brain.

1. I dey miss you: I miss you.

2. E go well: It works well, it works great. Can be used to assure someone that their outfit is paired nicely, their food tastes great, their hairstyle looks good on them and so on.
Dis food sweet well well: This phrase means  This meal is delicious . You can also say 'Dis food sweet no be small'.

1. I dey happy:I am happy.

2. Body dey catch me/you or Body dey sweet me/ you: I am/you are excited.

responses: The thing wey my eye don see, my mouth no go fit talk am: Meaning: What i have seen is too great to express with words. Used by people who have witnessed something extremely jarring/shocking, unbelievable or crazy. It is the equivalent of 'I am shook
You dey mad?:Are you mad?

1. Shey you dey whine me? You dey whine me? Are you kidding me?.

2. I no gree - I dont agree, I disagree.
Yahoo: Meaning: Cybercrime. Example: I want to go into yahoo bro, I m tired of my financial situation.
1. I go land you slap/I go slap you:I will slap you!. 2. Comot for my front:getout of my face, leave my presence.
Na ogun dey kee you? Is it Ogun (the deity) that torments you? Ogun kee you there: May ogun(the deity) kill you. Typically used to insult and imply that you are cursed.

1. No let body catch you o: Dont get too excited/cocky. Used as a warning to someone not to over step.

2. Body dey catch am: means they (may be a he or a she. Non gender specific. A generalization) are getting cocky. May also be used in neutral situations to merely point out that someone is excited.

responses: Where you know say you dey go?/ where you dey go? Meaning: Where do you think you're going to?/ Where are you going?
Breeze don blow, fowl yansh(yansh -> buttocks/derriere/backside) don open. Meaning: What was hidden has been exposed. A term used when a lie/falsehood has been unearthed/exposed

1. Na you i dey wait for/ I dey wait for you. Meaning: You are the one i am waiting for/I am waiting for you. 2. No be you i dey follow talk?/No be you i dey follow talk. Meaning: Aren't you the one i am speaking to?/ You are not the one i am speaking to. The are the same words but can mean different things altogether and the difference between them is highly dependent on your tone/pitch.

1. Now now or na na:
Immediately .

2. Where you dey go?- Where are you going? 
3. Which side you dey go? - What direction are you headed?

1. Wetin?: 
(weigh-teen) 
what?/What is it?.

2. Me sef: Me too.

1. We dey: We are(referring to an action to take) 
2. We be: We are(referring to description or introduction) 
3. E be (non-gender specific. applies to objects and animals as well): He/She/They are & 
She/he is.

1. You be = You are. 
2. He be = He is. 
3. She be = She is. 
4. Dem be( more than one) = They are.

5. Talk:Speak / say something 
6. Na so: 
It is so or correct
 7. Na so?: Is that so?.

No be so: 
Meaning: It is not so, 
That is not the way (usually involves an activity. 
Example: no be so dem dey wash motor or no be so e take happen (that is not how to wash a car or that's not how it happened).

1. I no get:I dont have.

2. Wetin dey happen?: Whats going on? ,  Whats happening?.

Abi/shey/ba: 
(ah-bee/ shay/ bah) 
English version: right? 
Example: You are coming to my party abi/shey/ba? (You are coming to my party, right?.

1. Sabi: (sah-bee) 
Know, understand, 
I nor no: I dont know. 
I no sabi: I dont understand or I dont know.

Na wetin I wan dey do now: Very similar to the tiktok skit that says (this is going to be my personality now).
Meaning: This is what I will always do going forward . It states the intent to adopt something as ones persona. 
Can be something positive or negative. It is mostly used for the negative but as a joke. 
Example: na wetin fit scatter pipo relationship dem won dey do now. 
Meaning: I have decided to start ruining peoples relationship going forward.
E no consign me/you: It is none of my/your concern, No be my consign/business: It is none of my concern/ business.

1. You say? / Wetin you say?. Meaning: You said? /What did you say?. 
May be used interchangeably. 
2. She/he/e say? : She/he/non gender specific said? 
3. She/he/e say wetin?: She/he/non gender specific said what?

Obodo Oyibo (oh-bow-dough-yee-bow):
From the Igbo Tribe.
Meaning - White man's land.

1. Baff up: 
Dress well or nicely.

2. Dash/ Dash me:
A gift/give it to me as a gift .

Doings: 
Used to describe the actions (lavish spending) of the Super Wealthy. 
Extravagance, 
opulence. 
Example: A person who throws a lavish party with the most expensive items or a person who purchases 
luxury cars or homes for friends, all their children etc. These acts are called doings.

1. Come chop: Come and eat.

2. Cruise: 
Meaning: To have fun, majorly by kidding around or teasing people.
Example: It is all cruise my guy.

Grab: 
Meaning: To understand. 
Example: Dont worry bro, I grab you.
Forget hand for your face: To slap someone. Example: I go forget my hand for your face.

Chop breakfast or serve breakfast: 
Chop breakfast: To be on the receiving end of heartbreak (romantic or otherwise).To be devastated.
Serve breakfast: To be the one doing the heart breaking, to be the cause of devastation. 
The intensity of the heartbreak is usually emphasized by adding hot before the breakfast i.e if it was ruthless, it will be described as hot breakfast ).
Can be used when describing a situation where someone committed the act.
Example: Have you heard that Sonia served David hot breakfast? (You hear say sonia serve david breakfast?).

Beef: 
Meaning: Keeping malice with someone. A form of hatred or jealousy towards someone. 
Example: Why are you beefing me bro?

1. Deck: 
Meaning: To punch. 
Example: Dont let me deck you.

2. Go slow: Traffic jam.

Billing: Meaning: Unnecessary expenses from third parties. 
Example: I don comot my hand for anything wey go attract billings.

Whine: 
Meaning: To tease someone. 
Example: I am just whining you to catch cruise

Sorosoke: 
(saw-raw-sow-kay)
It means to speak up. Was used during the End Sars protest to speak up against the Nigerian Law enforcements brutality against the nigerian youth.

Japa:
(jah-kpa)
To run, leave a place. In recent times it mostly means to relocate outside the country

Listen well-well: 
Pay attention,
Listen intently

Shayo:
(shah- yo) 
To drink alcohol.
Gi mi: Give me.

Crash.
Meaning: To sleep. 
Example: I m tired,  just want to crash

Rough.
Meaning: To manage something.
Example: No matter bro I go rough am.

Agba: 
(ah-gba) 
Meaning: A big boss. Mostly used to praise a rich person or to tease people. 
Example: You be agba now, show me love.

Wasere: 
(wah-shay-ray) 
Meaning: A word used to praise or appreciate someone after a benevolent act. Literally means  you will prosper.
Example: Thanks bro, wasere.

You too much: 
You are far too kind. 
Thank you. 
Good job!.

You be correct person/man/woman: You are a reasonable person, 
You are a savvy person, 
You are a likeable person. 
Typically used when someone is pleased with you or vice versa.

You be betta person/man/woman: You are a good person, you are a kind person, you are a nice person. 
Typically used when someone admires you or vice versa.
No such thing and if there is/are, it is wrong.

How far?- Hey, Hi, Hello

How bodi? ( bodi = boh-dee) / How you dey?/How na? 
Meaning: How are you doing today? 
You may respond by saying: 
I dey (I am fine), 
Bodi dey alright
I hail o: I hail you. Used as an acknowledgment and mostly in informal/casual settings.
Ekpa!!! How far na.Meaning: Whats up fool?.
Olodo welcome o. Meaning: Dullard/idiot you are welcome.
Same as positive.

Nigerians say words twice for emphasis. Examples include but are not limited to: 
1. Corner corner (kor-nah kor-nah: to cut corners). 
2. Mago mago (mah-go mah-go: fraud/cheat).
3. Lie lie (self explanatory). 
4. Well well (very much). 
5. Now now (immediately). 
6. Gra gra (grah grah: aggressive). 
7. Poto poto(pore-tore pore -tore: mud or muddy place). 
8. Yama yama(yah-mah yah-mah: dirt/something disgusting). 
9. Cry cry (cry baby). 
10. Follow follow(copy-cat). 
11. Fear fear(fearful person).
13. Bear bear(byeh byeh: beards). 
14. Borrow borrow (a consistent borrower).
15. Begi begi(beh-gee beh-gee: someone who begs all the time).
16. Know know (a know-it -all. Also known as an oversabi (ovah-sah-bee)).
17. Talku talku(tal-koo tal-koo: person who talks too much).
18. Shiny shiny(glitter or something sparkly for which the person has forgotten the words to use to describe).
The average Nigerian is peaceful and non-confrontational.
Nigerians love to laugh and so they like funny people.
There are over 500 indigenous languages spoken and more than 250 ethnic groups in Nigeria.
Lagos is Nigeria s largest city, but not its capital. Abuja is the capital of Nigeria.
Nigeria is the largest producer of oil and gas in Africa.

According to 'termcoord.eu: nigerian-pidgin-english', Nigerian Pidgin English (NPE) originated for trade purposes amongst the Nigerians and the Portuguese merchants during the 17th century.  It is broken English like Patois and Creole, spoken along the coast of West Africa and it has extended to the diaspora, due to Nigerian migrants.  After the departure of the missionaries, the language was retained and is the most widely spoken language in Nigeria today compared to English.

Please send your feedback to peace via email: peaceedogun@gmail.com. Be respectful.
